The green ammonia can contribute to the prevention of human health (SDG3). The act of ammonia deposition leads to the occurrence of eutrophication and acidity. Hence, it is imperative to consider these issues while formulating pertinent strategies to address this Sustainable Development Goal (SDG3). Ammonia emissions, constituting 13 % of agricultural emissions, result in an average increase of 0.36 μg/m3 in the population's exposure to particulate matter [170]. The substitution of conventional ammonia with environmentally friendly alternatives has the potential to mitigate the adverse effects associated with its use. This is mostly due to the fact that green technology relies on renewable energy sources.

The conventional production of ammonia from coal or coke over pathways creates impacts to the water bodies and sanitation. Therefore, appropriate technology for the green ammonia generation methods facilitates the distribution of potable water and sanitation services (SDG6). Irrespective of the specific raw material pathway employed, it is evident that the alteration in power input had the most significant effect. This underscores the imperative nature of implementing clean power sources within the synthetic ammonia sector.[171]. The application of nitrogen-based fertilisers in the agricultural sector has led to an increase in emissions associated with water pollution and acidification [172]. Therefore, it is advisable to substitute the excessive consumption of conventional ammonia with green ammonia in order to alleviate the adverse effects on the ecosystem, particularly in relation to agricultural wastewater. The production of green ammonia involves the use of sustainable energy sources, atmospheric components, and water, thus establishing a significant connection with SDG7. The utilisation of green ammonia as a zero-carbon energy storage and transport medium in various geographical regions, along with its cost-effectiveness in terms of transportation and storage, sets it apart from alternative approaches like underground hydrogen storage or geological storage of captured carbon. These alternatives incur higher costs for transportation and storage [13]. The production and transportation of ammonia are contingent upon the accessibility of RES and the existence of efficient and secure delivery methods. The energy efficiency of green ammonia generation using different production methods, namely hydropower, nuclear, biomass, and municipal waste, are close to be 42 %, 23 %, 15 %, and 12 %, correspondingly [173]. Furthermore, the viability of utilising ammonia in various applications is contingent upon the accessibility of ammonia inside urban areas. Ammonia exhibits compatibility with steel pipelines, with only minor adaptations to the existing infrastructure primarily designed for the transportation of natural gas and oil. By adopting this approach, the issue pertaining to the accessibility of ammonia will be resolved. The volumetric energy densities of liquid ammonia allow pipelines to transfer over 50 % more energy compared to the transportation of compressed natural gas [100].

The P2A2P technology is founded upon interdisciplinary linkages, wherein the battolysers serve to supply the grid with electrical energy. In addition to its primary functions, the grid has the capability to supply power to the ammonia manufacturing plant during periods of battolyser discharge or low wind conditions, ensuring the system is adequately heated and pressurised. Nevertheless, the implementation of a backup system is not necessary. The system exhibits a notable attribute of flexibility, wherein an additional amount of ammonia can be injected into the system from an external source [174]. The utilisation of green ammonia for decentralised power generation can be achieved through direct combustion in gas turbines or reciprocating engines, as well as through electrochemical dissociation in fuel cells. In addition, the green ammonia can be cracked in to hydrogen for the effective use in gas turbines and fuel cells [163]. By the year 2040, green ammonia is projected to emerge as a viable and economically competitive fuel option for generating zero-carbon energy through the use of highly efficient power plants. This development has the potential to significantly contribute to the economic prosperity of a nation, aligning with SDG8. The primary determinant of economic competitiveness in the transition from conventional ammonia to environmentally friendly alternatives is the prevailing cost of power in the local region. The fluctuation in fuel prices can be related to the differences between locally accessible and imported options. Additionally, several grids require diverse levels of capacity utilisation rates for dispatchable energy supplies. The economic ramifications associated with the development of green ammonia-based fertilisers, facilitated by the use of hydropower, demonstrate that green ammonia has the capacity to offset variations in hydropower output, spanning from 900 to 50 MW, and can potentially generate an additional power output of up to 370 MW [151]. The development and utilisation of green ammonia have a significant influence on various sectors of industry and infrastructure, aligning with SDG9. Followed by Sulfuric acid, ammonia as the second-largest chemical produced in industries. It serves as a primary precursor for several chemicals and synthetic fertilisers, functions as a refrigerant in refrigerators and air conditioning systems, holds significance as a chemical of importance in manufacturing industries, and serves as an alternative fuel in internal combustion engines as well as fuel cell-based power plants. In order to attain sustainability, it is imperative to advocate for the widespread adoption of green ammonia, which is produced from renewable energy sources, across all industries associated with ammonia [175]. A techno-economic feasibility analysis comparing the production of green ammonia to traditional ammonia production, using a reference capacity of 50,000 tons per year, revealed that the B2A process exhibits the highest level of exothermicity. However, this process is subject to significant restrictions due to the substantial amount of heat needed for acid gas scavenging. Nevertheless, the power-based ammonia production plant may pose a competitive threat if the payback period is less than five years [35]. The current surge in the exploration of green ammonia as a means to decarbonise the shipping industry serves as a strong indication of the manifold benefits associated with green ammonia. According to projections, the utilisation of green ammonia as a fuel in the maritime industry is expected to reach 99 % by the year 2050. The utilisation of ammonia, produced from water electrolysis results in a 27 % reduction in total GHG emissions, as opposed to its generation from natural gas fuel. The utilisation of a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) powered by green ammonia has the potential to be an optimal choice in marine transport, which is due to the significant reductions in both NOx and GHG emissions, up to 93.4 % and 92 % respectively, when compared to conventional systems [114,176]. Ammonia possesses the advantageous characteristic of serving as a versatile energy barrier, rendering it suitable for application as an environmentally friendly substance for fuel cells. The ammonia-based fuel cells provide several notable advantages, including their affordability, moderate working temperature, impressive efficiency, and exceptional durability. Additionally, they have the capability to use a wide range of fuel sources [177].

The utilisation of ammonia in power generation facilities and transportation systems has the potential to make significant contributions towards the achievement of sustainable cities and communities, as outlined in SDG11. The greenhouse gas emissions resulting from the utilisation of ammonia in transportation exhibit a notable reduction of over 60 % in comparison to vehicles powered by diesel and gasoline. A comparable pattern is evident in power plants that operate using natural gas [165]. The utilisation of green ammonia has the potential to substantially reduce or eliminate the presence of carbon dioxide and ammonia in minuscule quantities. During the process of conventional ammonia-fertiliser synthesis, natural gas is used as both an energy source and a processing gas. According to estimates, the production of one metric tonne of NH3 requires the use of approximately 35.2 GJ of natural gas [178]. Consequently, there is an observed rise in natural gas use per metric tonne of agricultural output. The utilisation of green ammonia has the potential to yield substantial savings in fossil fuel resources due to its reliance on renewable energy sources for production. This aligns with the objectives outlined in Sustainable Development Goal 12. One notable benefit of utilising green ammonia as an energy carrier lies in the fact that its primary constituent, nitrogen, is readily available in ample quantities throughout the environment [163,178]. The primary source of NH3 emissions is the agricultural sector, which accounts for around 55 to 56 % of global emissions [167]. There is a growing impetus to effectively respond to any alterations in the Earth's climate in alignment with SDG13. There is a growing trend in environmental regulation and investment towards the promotion of green technologies, which aim to mitigate the adverse effects of emissions on the environment. The production of ammonia via traditional energy sources resulted in the highest measured greenhouse gas emissions, amounting to 3.97 kg of carbon dioxide equivalent.

The burning of ammonia in power plants is responsible for a mere 6 % of the overall global warming potential, whereas the combustion of natural gas within these facilities is responsible for around 97 % of GHG emissions. In which the contribution of CO2 is approximately 98.6 %. This approach to harnessing the clean and abundant energy provided by wind power offers a sustainable solution for green ammonia production. Research has demonstrated that the substitution of traditional fuels with green ammonia has the potential to greatly alleviate the substantial impacts associated with power generation and urban mobility [165]. Even if a P2A2P system works without CCS, it could be economically viable; however, a CCS can make the P2A2P system the most cost-effective choice. [174]. The utilisation of ammonia is anticipated to have a detrimental impact on air quality due to the release of CO2 emissions during traditional ammonia production processes. Additionally, the application of ammonia as a fertiliser is expected to contribute to the generation of CO2 and nitrous oxide emissions. The emissions of NOx, specifically nitrous oxide (N2O), provide further contributions to climate change through the creation of nitric acid. There exists a correlation between the release of pollutants from soil and the occurrence of air pollution, similar to the correlation observed between the emission of pollutants from manufacturing plants and air pollution [178]. The enhancement of land productivity for agricultural endeavours, as outlined in SDG15, is positively influenced by the progressive adoption of green ammonia. The utilisation of green ammonia as a sustainable fertiliser has the potential to enhance agricultural productivity by increasing the yield of agricultural goods per unit area. Consequently, this would lead to a reduction in the amount of land required to produce each tonne of agricultural products [162]. Assessing the influence of green ammonia on water bodies poses challenges due to the multifaceted nature of its effects, which encompass the manufacturing stage, application, and subsequent discharge phases. There exist interrelated elements, including bodies of water and structures in close proximity to land. Conventional ammonia is also implicated in terrestrial ecotoxicity, as evidenced by studies indicating that higher quantities of fertiliser result in increased ecotoxicity [172,179]. The use of municipal solid waste for ammonia production had the lowest global warming potential when compared to the nuclear-based and biomass-based methods. The application of fertilisers has been shown to enhance crop yields. Therefore, a broader adoption of fertilisers could potentially reduce the amount of land needed for agricultural production, consequently mitigating the necessity to convert natural ecosystems into farmland. In the interim, the enhancement of fertiliser utilisation has the potential to mitigate the adverse environmental effects stemming from air pollution [51]. In order to enhance the global alliance for sustainable development (SDG 17), the utilisation of green ammonia is expected to facilitate the advancement of financial and technological aspects. Additionally, collaborative endeavours among nations will be fostered through the implementation of national legal measures, technology transfer, and integrated investment. The enhancement of the worldwide collaboration for the sustainable advancement of green ammonia will be achieved via the facilitation of financial resources and the promotion of technological advancements in the domain of sustainable green ammonia production. Enhancing global sustainability and fostering partnership among nations can be achieved by the implementation of national legislative laws, facilitating technological transfer, and promoting integrated investment. In order to accomplish this objective, it is imperative for states to provide support for the mobilisation of existing energy sources, facilitate the exchange of technologies, foster collaboration in the domain of research and technology, extend financial assistance to developing nations, ensure macroeconomic stability, and promote the sharing of financial resources [13,150,152].

The primary impediment to the synthesis of green ammonia is the substantial capital expenditure required. The synthesis of green ammonia via many strategies including the Haber process necessitates the utilisation of green hydrogen and nitrogen. Given that renewable energy sources are the primary means of power generation, it is crucial to consider the capital and maintenance costs associated with renewable energy generation systems. The challenges to green ammonia production encompass concerns regarding the dependability and sustainability of energy conversion technologies [101]. Despite the existence of several programmes aimed at promoting green ammonia production, the proportion of energy generated through these means remains relatively modest when compared to traditional methods. This discrepancy may be attributed primarily to various barriers and problems that must be effectively addressed in order to facilitate the widespread implementation of green energy technologies on an industrial scale. Green ammonia is an emerging energy supply technology that still faces numerous economic, financial, technical, and social obstacles before it can be considered mature. As a result, policy support is required to address the challenges posed by the aforementioned factor and enable the consideration of green ammonia as a feasible energy generation technique [150,180]. The primary obstacles to the production of green ammonia are the substantial financial investments and energy demands. The International Renewable Energy Agency projects that the demand for green hydrogen, which is utilised in the production of green ammonia, will increase substantially to 134–159 Mt by 2050. In order to generate the necessary quantity of green hydrogen, the capacities of offshore wind, onshore wind, and solar PV are 1,775, 2,243, and 4,240 GW, respectively. The same holds true for the production of green ammonia. The high CAPEX and renewable energy costs of electrolysers can be mitigated through the implementation of an appropriate supporting policy. Promoting the development of green ammonia production in nations abundant in renewable energy sources is an additional crucial policy. The introduction of green ammonia into the energy sector will have a substantial effect on the global temperature increase of 1.5 °C and make a valuable contribution to the pursuit of an energy policy with zero carbon emissions [23,116]. Similar to other industries, the primary impediment to the progress of the green ammonia sector is its high cost. Consequently, policies should take into account the cost of the CO2 emissions that are saved when green ammonia is utilised.

Green ammonia production is best suited in nations with favourable conditions for renewable energy sources as solar energy, wind, hydropower, or geothermal energy. Apart from electrical energy, fresh water and nitrogen are also needed in the manufacturing chain. A number of studies assessed the economic feasibility of producing and exporting green ammonia by taking into account the renewable energy sources that are available in the export destination as well as the expenses associated with shipping and pipe supply [181]. Given the strong correlation between green hydrogen and green ammonia, such studies are also taken into account when assessing the likelihood of discovering the probable countries. [182]. It was discovered that imports green ammonia from Morocco were more economically appealing to Belgium than local production [183] after 2030, though, the cost of producing and transporting green ammonia may become economically feasible. The viable application of green hydrogen and ammonia is studied in many countries including Australia, Chile, China, the US, Russia, Canada, India, the European Union, African states, the Middle East, Japan, and so on [115,181,182]. After 2030, this plan can be successfully implemented in nations like Australia that have abundant renewable energy resources (solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, etc.), as well as land, water, and maritime infrastructure [51,182,184].

Environmental impact of ammonia is directly correlated with its concentration in the surrounding environment. Ammonia poses significant health risks to both humans and other organisms. Hence, it is imperative to ensure that the exposure to ammonia, whether in the form of atmospheric gas, liquid, or fertiliser, remains within a specified threshold. One further environmental consequence of ammonia is its manufacturing process, which typically involves the utilisation of fossil fuels to produce hydrogen, separate nitrogen from the air, and convert nitrogen into ammonia NH3 [10,185]. The environmental impacts linked with the ammonia production process mostly stem from the release of CO2 emissions resulting from the conversion processes [186]. The transition from a fossil carbon energy-based economy to an ammonia-based one necessitates meticulous evaluation of the environmental consequences stemming from the production and use of this novel fuel. It is crucial that humanity does not evade one issue related to CO2 emissions only to create another crisis regarding NH3 and NOx emissions. The issue of growing nitrate concentrations and their impact on marine ecosystems requires heightened attention [101]. While there is a considerable amount of research available on the techno-economic elements of ammonia production and transport, the analysis of environmental implications is very few. According to Gilbert et. Al [187], combining biomass gasification with ammonia production can decrease 65 % of greenhouse gas emissions compared to the traditional method. A comparative investigation of the life cycle of NH3 production through electrolysis, using energy from hydro, nuclear, biomass, and municipal waste sources, revealed that biomass-based ammonia production was more environmentally sustainable for the specific locations in Algeria and Mexico [188]. According to Arora et. al [189], a biomass-based ammonia production system on a modest scale can decrease emissions by up to 64 % when compared to traditional systems. Chemical looping integration offers a viable solution for mitigating CO2 emissions [190]. Considering the CO2 emissions related to the entire ammonia supply chain, it is possible to achieve a 36 % decrease in CO2 emissions for power generation using ammonia compared to a natural gas combined cycle with carbon capture and storage. Chemical looping hydrogen production can generate highly concentrated streams of H2 and N2. Furthermore, by eliminating the air separation unit, energy consumption is significantly lowered by around 60 %, which results in a more sustainable alternative for hydrogen generation. Conversely, there was a 60 % increase in emissions to water and a 30 % rise in emissions to soil due to the greater amount of water being transferred to the wastewater treatment plant. Switching to renewable electricity sources can further reduce emissions in natural gas-based ammonia synthesis methods, particularly in terms of air emissions [191].

Conventional ammonia production emits carbon dioxide emissions at 1.8 % rate [50], for example, 2.2 kg CO2 per kilogramme of NH3 was released [10]. Therefore, green ammonia from RES received much attention. The emission of ammonia into the atmosphere leads to a chemical reaction with atmospheric moisture, resulting in the formation of ammonium. The presence of ammonium in precipitation can result in an elevation in the osmotic concentration of the soil [185]. A concentration as low as 0.02 parts per million (ppm) has been found to have lethal effects on delicate marine organisms [192]. The presence of ammonia can have substantial implications for human health due to its ability to generate a potent alkaline solution, leading to skin irritation, respiratory system discomfort, and eye irritation. The threshold limit for the unpleasant odour of ammonia is 5 parts per million (ppm), which serves as an indicator of the presence of NH3 in the surrounding environment. Exposure above 134 ppm has been associated with significant noise and throat irritation. When the concentration of a substance exceeds 2000 parts per million (ppm), it might have fatal consequences for an individual. Additionally, exposure to high concentrations of this substance can result in severe skin related health issues [52]. The availability of land for the establishment of new production and handling facilities is constrained. Therefore, future research endeavours should prioritise the development and enhancement of conventional ammonia production facilities.

While there are established technologies for the manufacture, transportation, and utilisation of traditional ammonia, there are numerous technical challenges associated with its capacity, feasibility, infrastructure, labour expertise, and production and utilisation viability. Within the realm of RES, it is widely acknowledged that wind and solar energy exhibit the greatest promise for the large-scale production of environmentally friendly ammonia. Additional barriers that warrant consideration include the efficiency of direct green NH3 synthesis, as well as factors pertaining to availability, reliability, and maturity.

In order to address the issue of the elevated cost of green ammonia resulting from its limited energy efficiency caused by fluctuations in renewable power and substantial investment expenses, a hybrid approach was adopted by integrating a liquid air energy storage system with a power-to-ammonia system. This combination aimed to effectively manage the uncertainties associated with both power supply and demand. The traditional P2A method, which operates with a grid connection, is inadequate for managing the uncertainties associated with fluctuations in renewable energy sources and utility electricity prices. Using a LAES in conjunction with a green ammonia and electricity co-production system, these uncertainties can be managed. LAES is a relatively new method for storing energy on a large scale that features a substantial transit efficiency of 50–60 %, an energy storage density of approximately 200 kWh/m3 [193], exceptional safety performance [194], and a minimal levelized cost of storage [195]. This technology has demonstrated technical and economic viability, as evidenced by the construction of multiple commercial facilities in the United Kingdom and the United States. Furthermore, due to its exceptional energy storage efficiency, extended storage endurance, and secure operation, it can function as a buffer to mitigate the risks associated with power supply and demand fluctuations in the P2A process. By incorporating LAES into a P2A process, ammonia was produced with a P2A efficiency and a specific energy consumption of 83 % and 7.4 kWh/kg NH3, respectively. A minimum cost of 360.74 euros per tonne can be achieved for ammonia production along with 77 % inclusion of renewable energy sources. As the dispatchable electricity price and peak electricity price increased from 150 to 250 €/tonne, there was a substantial reduction in the levelized cost of NH3 (LCONH3) from 587.0 to 122.7 €/tonne [194,196]. Furthermore, to increase its round-trip efficacy, LAES is capable of absorbing external thermal energy, such as the cold energy of liquefied natural gas [60] and low-grade waste heat from industry [197].

The utilisation of high-temperature electrolysis is made possible through the implementation of the continuous P2A process, which in turn leads to the attainment of a remarkable production efficiency of 83 % through the integration of system thermal components. [196]. Nevertheless, alternative approaches are also used for the direct production of ammonia, which are deemed to be more advantageous in terms of efficiently harnessing RES. The primary obstacle confronting these methodologies is their limited conversion efficiency. Fortunately, ongoing research and development endeavours are currently focused on enhancing efficiency levels by up to 60 % through the utilisation of electrochemical techniques [198]. Despite having been in existence since 1920, the primary focus of transitioning to green synthesis is predominantly centred around the production cost and capacity of the electrolyser [92,199,200]. Nevertheless, the current unconventional approaches to green ammonia synthesis are not yet feasible for implementation in commercial settings, and thus, necessitating additional investigation. The widespread accessibility of RES promotes the decentralised production of environmentally friendly ammonia. Nevertheless, it is imperative to accurately forecast economic considerations due to the regional variations in renewable energy sources. In addition, the storage and management of green ammonia in large amounts poses a significant challenge due to the uneven accessibility of renewable energy sources and the lack of appropriate technologies for securely handling the flammable ammonia in decentralised storage facilities [95,201]. The investigation and innovation process There exists a dearth of comparative analyses that examine the distinctions between green ammonia and traditional ammonia production methods that incorporate carbon capture and storage technologies. In addition to direct research, there is a need for indirect research in the field of renewable energies. This includes doing life cycle assessments on the resources utilised in these energy sources. For instance, in wind generation, elements. Thorough and comprehensive investigations are necessary prior to the transfer from the traditional process to newly developed green synthesis. Efficient catalysts are required for the activation of nitrogen gas, as indicated by the thermodynamic potential [202]. A research gap exists in the field of ammonia technology, specifically pertaining to challenges associated with the separation of unreacted materials and the subsequent low yield of ammonia under low pressure conditions. Consequently, there is a need to explore alternative catalysts that are both highly selective and efficient in order to address these issues.

One of the foremost obstacles pertains to the direct synthesis of ammonia, bypassing the requirement for an intermediate stage involving hydrogen generation. The synthesis of ammonia directly without an intermediate H2 generation stage represents a noteworthy advancement in the effort to reduce the cost associated with ammonia production. Another significant strategy entails the endorsement of green ammonia manufacturing inside nations abundant in renewable energy resources. In the global energy utilisation, the incorporation of green ammonia can contribute to limiting the atmospheric temperature increase in accordance to the IEA expectations (below 1.5 °C), while also making a significant contribution to the implementation of a zero-carbon emission energy strategy [23]. The findings of a research investigation examining the utilisation of ammonia in maritime transportation indicate that the utilisation of green ammonia derived from solar energy results in a substantial decrease of 45.4 % in CO2 emissions. This reduction is observed when the fuel energy fraction of ammonia is 95 %. Additionally, it was observed that the use of ammonia derived from wind energy leads to a 50 % reduction in CO2 emissions when the fuel energy fraction is 60 %. Moreover, the utilisation of green ammonia derived from wind energy aligns with the established objective for the year 2050 by delivering a substantial decrease of 79.2 % in carbon dioxide emissions when employed as a fuel energy component of 95 %. Nevertheless, the adoption of green ammonia appears to be less attractive until its cost is reduced to a justifiable extent [186]. One of the most crucial policies entails the reduction of substantial cost disparities between conventional and green ammonia production. The infrastructure of green ammonia is also subject to numerous technical constraints [66]. Similar to other industries, cost is one of the major issues in the implementation of green ammonia technologies. Regrettably, the cost is nearly four times greater than that of conventional ammonia. Hence, it is imperative to establish rules that consider the financial implications associated with the allocation of reserved carbon dioxide emissions in the context of utilising green ammonia. Moreover, it is imperative to adopt a comprehensive and secure policy approach in order to effectively address the challenges associated with the transportation and storage of green ammonia [6], which will lay a platform for commercialization of green ammonia in near future.

Renewable ammonia can be a desirable alternative in current energy systems like internal combustion engines and power generation. The non-linear and variable nature of renewable energy makes it crucial to deploy green ammonia at a conventional, decentralised level for these applications. Conventional systems that rely on grid electricity or fossil fuels must have a consistent energy supply. Hence, it is imperative to implement suitable energy storage systems to effectively incorporate ammonia-based energy supply [203]. Moreover, the implementation of extensive ammonia facilities, storage infrastructure, and transportation systems has the potential to produce electricity for the power grid or serve as a source of fuel for marine transportation. A technique like this can facilitate the seamless integration of conventional and green ammonia-based systems. The energy system is crucial and fundamental in the integration of renewable energy sources for providing heat and power, facilitating the shift towards a sustainable society. Hence, it is important to construct energy systems that rely on environmentally friendly and sustainable sources, while also incorporating efficient storage and transportation systems, in order to successfully accomplish the objectives of energy efficiency, sustainable development, and smart cities. Renewable energy conversion systems, like solar PV and wind, exclusively generate electrical energy. In contrast, solar concentrated collectors and biomass systems have the capability to produce both thermal and electrical energy. Furthermore, in order to ensure a consistent and consistent provision of various energy sources, it is essential to have storage and transportation systems and technologies in place. Various research in the literature have explored the integration of renewable energy sources, including wind, sun, biomass, and geothermal, to provide energy for different uses [204]. Nevertheless, a comprehensive investigation will be conducted to examine the function of green ammonia-based systems through active research. Ammonia offers several benefits as an energy storageand transport medium. It is dependable, inexpensive, and has high energy density. In addition to providing direct heat, hydrogen, and electricity, ammonia has the potential to play a significant role in the future energy scenario.

The transformation of reactive nitrogen constituents, such as ammonia, has played a significant role in shaping the worldwide energy panorama. Approximately 80 % of ammonia production is mostly allocated for use in fertilizers, but it also has usage in direct ammonia fuel cells (DAFC) and as hydrogen energy storage vectors. The global issue of reactive nitrogen accumulation in the atmosphere is a result of this phenomenon [205]. Without the application of N-fertiliser, around 30 % of the global food crops would be lost [65]. Simultaneously, the rising pattern in production and utilisation has resulted in several environmental issues, including global acidification, ozone depletion, eutrophication, and climate change [92,121]. The progress in developing technologies for producing environmental-friendly ammonia, the current state of technical demonstrations and commercialization of these technologies, and the evaluation of costs, CO2 emissions, and energy efficiency of different ammonia production methods, are highlighting the importance of global cooperation in achieving the goal of decarbonization by 2050 [206]. There has been a growing interest in constructing decentralised energy systems that utilise hydrogen and ammonia storage to maintain a balanced operation. The need for diversification of energy production directions and sources of energy supply is more significant in light of the current global energy crisis and escalating energy prices [207]. Regarding the level of cooperation among nations, it was noted that North American and European countries exhibit a comparatively elevated degree of international collaboration when it comes to hydrogen-based distributed energy systems. Countries in South America, Africa, East Asia, and Oceania seem to have a diminished degree of international collaboration. To foster collaboration among the aforementioned countries, it is imperative to execute multiple simultaneous measures [208]. The phases involve forming regional alliances, enhancing communication networks, investigating possibilities for financial assistance or collaborative funding of initiatives and investments, and advocating for the alignment of strategies among countries within each region.

A widely recognized carbon-free fuel is green ammonia in recent times. Ammonia produced by the Haber-Bosch process from renewable sources has find its application in various sectors i.e., hydrogen energy carrier, fertilizer, electricity, and heating. An extensive review of literature dealing with the application of ammonia was analysed and discussed in this review. To begin with, the importance of ammonia as an energy carrier molecule or hydrogen energy-carrier in the renewable fuel sector, Power-to-ammonia-to-power (P2A2P) system, and the involvement of green ammonia to SDGs was reviewed. Further, technological challenges and the environmental impact of green ammonia in making a feasible fuel were given in-detail. The difficulty of separating unreacted components and the ensuing inferior ammonia production under low-pressure circumstances are areas of the green ammonia process where knowledge gap exists and therefore, efficient and highly selective alternative catalysts need to be investigated to solve this limitation. Significant challenges in the areas of economics, finance, technology, and societal acceptance must be addressed in order to advance this concept. Hence, policy assistance is necessaryto facilitate the elimination or reduction of these hurdles, so enabling the transformation of green ammonia into a feasible manufacturing technique. Furthermore, considering ammonia as an energy carrier, it is urgent to implement appropriate policy measures to effectively address the challenges associated with the transportation and storage of green ammonia.
